title: 103_s2007
content: The "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act of 1994" authorizes the minting of $1 silver coins with specific specifications. The coins will contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper, weigh 26.73 grams, and have a diameter of 1.500 inches. The silver for minting the coins will be sourced from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins minted under the "George C. Marshall Commemorative Coin Act of 1994" must feature George C. Marshall on the obverse side, along with inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "1995", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS: Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from January 1, 1995, using only one facility of the United States Mint for each quality. Minting authority terminates on December 31, 1995. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales will include a $7 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for the Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to Friends of George C. Marshall for memorial construction. The Comptroller General can audit the funds. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the government for minting coins. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
